text: can 5.6%. Poured deep amber with a fluffy beige head. Bold citrusy hop aroma. Medium-full body, average carbonation, tart mouthfeel with lingering bitterness. Complex flavour, heavy on the malt. Spicy notes of rye, orange peel, pine notes, resinous hops.

Clear, faint hazy, copper color with goods amount of activity. Slightly creamy light brown 2 finger head, lasting around 5-10 minutes, with good legs. Flavors of pineapples, orange, lemon, grass, brown sugar, ginger, sweet grains, nutmeg, and herbal spices. Biscuits and bread feel, quite sugary and a little syrupy, with a dash of bitter earthy hops. Smooth and slick full body with soft crispy carbonation. Slightly dry moderate to strong finish, very hoppy with not enough malt and zest, lingering toffee, red ale spices, and tropical fruits, with grassy and leafy hops. A cross between an IPA and ESB, but feels more like a hoppy Irish ale. Very tasty flavors and good freshness. Nicely balanced and well intensified. Overall very good quality craft.
All around good tasting beer - lots of flavour and malt depth, more interesting than the average ESB with the drinkability and smoothness. Rich malt eases into a roast nut finish that is great.

Fluffy off-white head with solid lacing. A deep mahogany body. A big citrus nose, led by grapefruit rind, and a touch of caramel malt. This is no ESB, but I wont hold that against it. Biting rindy American hops lead the taste profile. Nicely astringent. support is provided by roasted caramel malt, some rye spice and a late touch of lemon. Some pine resin lurks around the finish as well. a real gripper.

can. pours unclear bright red-pink with a nice off-white cap offering some retention and lacing. tons of fruity caramelized maltiness, sweetish english specialty malts, tons of spicy american C hops, lots of strawberry fruitiness, pepper and pine as well, watermelon juice, citrus-infused english tea notes, clean yeast. moderate carbonation, light body - oily; balanced spicy-citrusy finish. notwithstanding its alleged styles (esb/irish red), its rather an old school ipa or an assumed red ipa with an english malt bill.

Lots of nuances on the nose: citrus (particularly orange and tangerine), some sort of exotic tropical fruit (guava?), floral notes and a honey-like sweetness. Caramel malts, toffee, more citrus and resin on the tongue. Quite bitter for the ABV. I like this quite a bit.

Mar 2, 2016 can. Pours a clear copper ruby with a finger of off white head that thins to a thick, bubbly film and sticks to the glass. Aroma has notes of bread, caramel, resin, pine, citrus, faint floral, and hints of tropical fruits like pineapple. Taste is balanced but on the bitter side. I think the hops have fallen a touch. Resin, pine, citrus, bread, caramel, faint floral, and a drawn out, bready, resiny, bitter ending. Medium-full body with a medium carbonation. Mildly resiny in the mouth with a dry finish. Overall not bad. I should have tried it sooner. Resin, citrus, pine, caramel, bread, and a dry finish.

Pours the colour of an old penny, with a perfect two finger head. Its a beautiful blend of hops, malts, red fruits, and caramel. Definitely getting ESB characteristics, which I see now this used to be marketed as. Pretty tasty stuff.

Can from LCBO. Very sweet caramel aroma, with noticeable orange juice and slight hops. Appearance is clear red, almost brown; frothy head that mostly dissipates; some lacing . Potent toffee off the start that almost immediately cedes to grassy and citrusy hops. Slight mineral bitterness kicks in about half way and lingers, otherwise excellent. Really tasty and drinkable, fits solidly between the IPA and ISA.
Amber to dark red color. Aroma is hoppy. Taste is the same but has a very nice creamy mouthfeel, very good beer

Pours a large frothy beige head and has an amber coppery appearance. Thick dirty lacing. Aromas earthy hops, hints of caramel and sweet malts. Flavours are also quite sweet and malty with lots of caramel malta and earthy resin hop notes. Has a bit of bitterness to it, not too much but just enough. Some sweetness on the palate to even things out. Quite flavourful and easy to drink.
Can. Pours a deep copper almost red, off white head, small layers of lace. Nose is sweet and malty. Tastes bitter, a little caramel. A lot more hop presence than Im used to for an ESB. Drinkable.

Confusion abounds with this poorly defined & marketed beer. Formerly an ESB; now they call an Irish red (its neither). Assume they will reformat the style again next year. Decent ipa style hop bitterness, with a malt forward edge. Hints of pepper, grain seems like rye, the hops are leafy & somewhat sticky. Strong mineral presence. Enjoyable, if not a bit too thick in the finish. Its ok but may as well just have their regular ipa.

Pour is a beautiful copper colour with a persistent tan cap that leaves some nice lace. Fruity/toasty malt with some grassy hops. Toastiness really comes through in the taste, and helps put this a small notch about a standard amber. Light mineral taste, like bitterness on the finish. Simple and easy-drinking.

473 ml can from LCBO, served quite cool in a tulip glass. 
App.: Clear copper with a fair reddish-tan head.
 
Aroma: Earthy and lightly fruity (berries) malt, a bit of toffee/caramel, fairly bright citrus hops, a bit peppery and resinous, kinda floral, dark bread crust veering on rye bread crust, faint booze.
 
Palate: Medium+ body, moderate-ish bitterness.
 
Flav.: Fairly pungent citrus hops with lighter peppery/resinous notes, crunch yet dry malt with big bread crust and a hint of berries/toffee, lightly earthy; dry with fairly big bitterness and a citrusy, peppery, bread crust malt finish.

Nice stuff. An Irish Ale? Cmon.
Transparent Amber color, not much foam. Nice bitterness, some hoppiness. Hard to beat.

Can 0.5L bought in BC liquor store. Pours a hazy dark amber. Aroma is hoppy, flowers, grassy, caramel. Taste is hoppy bitterness (piney, grass). Hoppy bitterness, roasted malt, notes of bread and tropical fruits in aftertaste. Very good, especially taking into account the cheap price.

Aroma - medley of citrus hops, floral, and resin hops. Lemon and pineapple close to the outer skin.
Appearance - body is mahogany in color, slight haze. The head is off-white, 2". Very foamy, and settles slowly. Some lacing.
Taste - rich caramel malt, with Pacific Northwest hops of the citrus, floral, and resin variety. Citrus quality has a mix of lemon, less grapefruit, and just a dash of pineapple.
Palate - medium body, not oily, average carbonation, and medium length bitter.

Rating #1375 11.12.2014 341mL Bottle from the CC/P49 Mystery Box. Bottle says Red Racer ESB. Pours a dark amber with a foamy off-white head that dissipates slowly, medium-strong retention. Aroma is mild toasted malt, hints of wildflowers. Hop presence is significant, giving the bitter character, but the breadiness of the malt is what makes this beer. Creamy mouthfeel Well balanced, medium bodied ale that is easy to drink.
Light citrus and some good malt backbone. Pours red with good head and lacing. Light sweet malt finish. Good balance, and nice little beer. Tap at Barley Bros Stadium.

Can as ESB from Bishops Cellar, Halifax. It pours clear red-amber with a decent yellow-white head. The nose is juicy, piney, bitter-sweet, Victoria sponge cake, jammy and biscuit. The taste is bitter-sweet, piney, varnish, leafy, nuttiness, jammy, berry, peppery spice and cake with a dry, spiced finish. Medium body and average carbonation. Not an ESB by any measure. Decent nonetheless.

Bottle: Poured a clear copper color ale with a nice off-white foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of caramelized malt with solid citrus hops notes. Taste is also dominated by caramelized malt with some light residual sugar notes offset by some dominated citrus oriented hops notes. Boyd is light with good carbonation. Not really close to an Irish ale or and ESB considering the amount of hops in this beer but enjoyable nonetheless.
can: not a huge fan of this one. is it an esb or a red? not really similar in style. this comes across as a lightly hoppy red ale, but also a little dusty. not bad, but not impressed either.
Yuck. I obviously got an extremely old bottle (labeled as ESB) because it literally poured out of the bottle as foam. Gross metallic taste. Willing to try a new rebranded bottle and re rate then.
On tap at Beertown, under the name "ESB". Surprising citrus aroma. Bready caramalt taste with bright floral and citrus hops. Good balance of bitter and sweet. Not really an ESB, but a nice "IRA".

Visual: Pours cloudy light root beer brown with minimal head, a thin layer of fine retention, several streams of varied speeds.

Nose: bright grapefruit hops with some metallic muskiness, hints of jasmine (lvl-7)-pungency

Attack: immediate bitter hop assault, crisp fizzy-tingly mouthfeel

Mid-palate: (lvl-4)-sweetness, (MAIN) toffee malts, citrus hops, tangerine-grapefruit peel, 

Finish: lingering biting hopped bitterness, burpy, dry finish.

Summary: To me this is like a less fruity-more malty drier IPA, but still very bitter. Not 100% my style of beer but decent nonetheless. The nose is great.

500ml can in to a pint glass. Nice red, leaning on the copper side. Mellow head, not over carbonated. Smells like a mix of caramel and piney hop. Tastes like it smells but better. Hop hit first and smooth caramel malt wash almost instantaneously. Like that balance. Lovely. Nobody talks about this stuff on this site but I paid less than $2.50 for this beer in BC. Thats robbery for this beaut of a beer.

Can into pint glass. Pours a slightly hazy copper colour with a little cap of off white head. Aroma is slightly fruity hops. Taste is a little malty with nice hop flavour. Good beer.

-- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10

16 oz can to half-pint glass (thanks cards04). Looks good; a slightly hazy amberish brown with very light caramel head. Smells solid; bittersweet from the hops and malt along with some toastiness. Tastes like it smells with some tropical fruit, caramel, and a touch of pine as well. Pleasant on the palate with a medium-bodied mouthfeel. Im normally not a fan of IRAs, but this works nicely.

ENG: Can poured into a glass. Color is amber-reddish with nice tan colored foam. Aroma is a bit pine, a bit citrus with caramel malt. Taste is caramel-malty plus hoppy-bitter but not overwhelmed. Very balanced. Overall its a tasty easy-drinkable beer. Kind of surprise that a beer from a can could be also great in taste. /////~//////////////////////////////////////////// PL: Puszka przelana do szkła. Kolor ciemno bursztynowy, czerwonawy z łądną gęstą jasną pianą. Aromat karmelowy, lekko sosnowy i cytrusowy. W smaku głównie karmelowo-słodowy z domieszką chmielowej goryczki, ale nie jest nią przeładowany. Dość zbalansowane - lekkie pijalne piwo. Bardzo dobre jak na piwo z puszki.
Not much head great but great lacing. Taste is of pine hops and malt sweetness. Has just the right amount of bitterness at the end.

Thanks to Reimer for this. Pours a foggy brown with a small off white top. Aroma is pine and grapefruit hops and caramel malt. Taste is more pale ale than esb but its fantastic, great maltiness coupled with a smooth grapefruit and pine hop. Wish this was available locally.

Aroma is citrus, lemon grass, earthiness and clove. A light sweet malt character can be traced. Taste is a light sweet maltiness which is met by a fairly dominant hop profile. The earthiness and tanin tastes carry through until finish and cloaks any of the deeper malt character. Appearance is a clear copper with a very thich creamy head that retains fabulously.

Pale copper amber, bubbly tan head, low retention and lots of of lacing. Aroma is floral, pine, and resin. Taste is sweet, bread, and caramel. Finishes floral and bitter, lingering. Body is light, slightly sticky. Carbonation is strong and foamy. Not bad.
Bottle - Caramel and some piney sweet hops. Clear copper with a rich beige head. Caramel and resinous hops, bitter and sweet. Smells much better than it tastes.

Central City consistently proves that very good things come in cans. I am taking this as more of a Red IPA than anything else even though I got the ESB labelled can. Right away, the rufescent copper with its light beige hits gets you ready for what is soon to come; a very fresh, very potent pine, resin, earthy hop punch balanced by toasty biscuit and caramel malt strength. I detect slight hints if grapefruit as well. Pleasantly bitter but not puckering, this brew has a medium body with mid soft carbonation. Not surprisingly a very enjoyable potion.
Tall can. Caramel and roasty, toasty malt. resiny/citrusy hop. Earthy and substantial. Good body. Great bitterness.

This beer is very tasty... taste close to the Red Racer IPA which is a very nice beer too. The medium body was crisp, clean and smooth, with a pleasantly dry finish. Drinkability was very good, bordering on excellent...
Fantastic call for the change of name from ESB to Red Ale
I poured from a bottle into a pint glass and noticed a pleasant aroma. Large head dissipated quickly. Once the glass was empty residue on the sides of the glass felt sticky and tasted bitter.

355 ml can from Premier Wine and Spirits (as Red Racer ESB). Pours a lightly cloudy amber/copper colour with moderate-sized cream-coloured head. Aroma is caramel, grains and a fairly robust spicy/piney hoppiness. Flavour has a fairly rich caramel and bready maltiness with solid spicy/resiny bitterness. Average plus body. Nice one.

Tasted at the edmonton craft beer festival. Some hints of piney and slight citrus hop. Biscuity malt taste with decent bitterness. Pretty good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice copper color on this one with a slightly off white head. Aromas of pine, slight citrus (grapefruit/orange). Caramel and bready notes. Taste is nice. Slight bitter pine up front rolls briefly into a mint/leafy note into the caramel/bready sweet malt. Finishes with a slight hop spice and citrus pop. Moderate carb, nice body for 5.6%

Smells rich, malty, molasses, hoppy, slight hints of tropical fruit. Pours brown, clear with a thick beige head. 

Tastes bitter, but not in a NW way, burnt malt, bread crust, slightly sweet with piney overtones. The body is in the thicker side, lightly carbonated bitter finish. 

Over all a nicely crafted beer, however I think their IPA is more my style.

Probably one of the best and most quaffable ESBs I have ever had. With a balanced taste of caramel,bread, and nuts, she went down smooth, and finished with a welcoming bitter end. I could always finished the six pack, it was so good.
Poured from 355mL can. Clear, copper with off-white head. Quite dry hoppy with mild caramel malt. Medium body.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2014 Bottle. Deep reddish amber colour with a pillowy off-white head. Aroma is hoppy, lots of grapefruit and a touch of honey. Flavour is fairly bitter with a stiff hop presence, grapefruit and lemon zest, but finishes with some sweetness, a touch of honey and tropical fruits. Quite tasty.

Bottle thanks to Matt! Pours a clear deep amber orange with a near white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of pine with some resin and a grain backbone with a touch of sweetness. Flavor is a bit less hoppy but still has light resin and pine with some sweet grains and bread backing.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 On tap at The Met in New Westminster. An appealing dark copper color with a bit of light tan head and a lot of malt on the nose. A bit bitter-sweet at first, followed by sweet and earthy malts. Bitter after-taste. 
Hard to believe this beer has been around since 2004 and Im just getting around to reviewing it now! A nice one.
And Aug 19, 2014 on tap at the brewpub in Surrey. A dark amber with a bit of light coloured head. A very assertively hopped beer with strong malted backbone. Yes!
Hazy deep, deep amber with half inch of pillowy foam. Amazing fresh floral hoppy aroma, with fruity/caramel malt. Bold flavour but kept in balance. Bitter finish is bracing. Nice.
Amber in the glass; nice carbonation - subdued head; citrus on the nose and palate; crisp, bitterness is balanced- overall a great  example of an extra bitter beer

Pours a clear light - medium brown with a medium sized off white head and a lot of lace. Aroma is earthy, tropical fruits, light pine and sweet caramel. Taste is sweet caramel malts, grapefruit, pine, tropical fruits, and a nice well balanced mild-medium bitterness.

Always love me a bitter. Pours a lovely red amber with lacy white foam with a great aroma of hops and citrus. Flavour is divine; grapefruit and tangerines, bitter hops surprisingly well balanced with a sweet malt that goes down very nicely. I cant call it my favourite beer, because that list is packed tight with heavy Belgians, but ESB is right up there on my personal charts for excellent beers.
On tap. Pours brown with medium head. Aromas of caramel, light pine, and roasted malt. Flavors of caramel, grapefruit, and malts. Yep maybe some maple. Very nice but sweet and fruity for an ESB.

Pours a clear medium brown with a nice big frothy light brown head. Aroma of sweet caramel, grassy hops, earth but basically a nice light esb aroma to style. Taste is caramel, grass, earth and maybe even some maple hints with a nice bitterness through. Excellent bitter all around... Waited a long time to try this one and it was worth it.

On tap at sunset. Pours clear amber, steady, white cap reducing to heavy rope and an island of skim. Aroma of earth/dust, caramel, and a bit of pine. Taste is similar, but some maple leaps in. Weird. I've had this beer before, but haven't tasted the maple. Good dryness. Well balanced.
smell is pretty basic and not overly impressive but makes up for it in taste possibly one of the best bitters i have ever had whoever brewed this beer mad props to you

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2013 Ambrée foncé, un peu roux. Une grande mousse beige qui reste jusquau fin. L?arôme d?houblon avec un peu de malt. Le goût est d?abord du malt et caramel ensuite d?houblon avec un amertume moyenne en finale. Très équilibré et très bonne.

Cask days 2012.
Huge leafy, green hoppy aroma, sweet malts, and touches of minerals. 
Good mouthfeel, expected low carb, medium bitterness. This is a new world approach to an ESB. Finish is again huge on hops with some nice bready malts. And ESB and APA hybrid.

Cask at Alibi Room, Vancouver. Brown in color, no head (cause its cask, duh). Very little aroma. Very traditional ESB, medium/thin body, complex mouthfeel very smooth. Finish is superb, long and complex. I dont usually go for this kind of style, but Central City does a great job here.

On tap at cask fest 2012  
Aroma:    leafy , clean feel with medium intensity. Refined mature approach to ESB world. 
Look:  hazed amber gold ale with mild carbonation. 3+
Taste/palate:   Medium bodied. Sweet malts  with floral hops. Light carbonation. Very smooth.
Pours good golden colour.  Hoppy aroma from the pour was inviting, strong and delicious.  Taste was hoppy, and good strong bitter throughout.  On cask at Torontos cask days festival.
Finally tried this beer, after hearing so much good about it. I wasnt disappointed. This is a strong tasting beer, but the flavour is a very pleasant one. Hoppy, bitter and delicious.

Cette rouquine nous montre son décolleté au travers une mousse épaisse et dense tout en laissant paraître une dentelle. Son parfum est tout de fleurs et dherbes disparates et de miel de verge dor. Elle laisse un goût amer en bouche, civilisée comme une anglaise du genre. Ça nécorche pas, cest empreint de politesse. On laimerait aussi "wild" que sur létiquette sauf que ça reste une matante. (297-050812)

The hops certainly take centre stage in this one. Toffeish earthy fruit hops... caramelize some sort of wild berry and youre well on your way to making the solid nonalcoholic version of this beer. Its the berry finish Im looking for in the ESB, so this is a real winner. Ill have lots more in the future.
Cool lookingng can. Fruity smell, very bitter hoppy after taste. Shocked me at first. But pretty good, Id buy it again.
Pours an amber colour. Smells like citrus, honey and resin. Balanced sweetness on the tongue with a bitter finish. Very drinkable. Really liked this.
Aroma of grapefruit, grapes, honey. Taste is bitter hops, sweet malts, honey. Red colour with white (quickly fading head). A solid ESB.

A orange amber ale with a thick frothy mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity malt with grassy British hops, some treacle, nice. In mouth, a nice caramel malt with burned sugar, nice herbal British hops, a bit piney, nice and smooth. Can.

The beer pours a amber color with a light white fluffy head. The nose light citrus rind with hints of pine, hops and malt. The body is medium weight. The flavor starts with a malty pine followed by a floral lite hoppiness and finishes with a bitterness that lingers but not to intense. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Une courtoisie de papat444)  Un liquide à la robe orangée.  Une belle mousse.  Un nez de houblons fruités.  Des notes florales.  Une bouche encore une fois mal définie.  Des houblons inintéressants.  Une base maltée déficiente.  Des notes âcres.  Un corps maladif.  Un pétillement incontrôlable.  Une texture légère.  Une finale sur des notes métalliques.

Canette gracieuseté de Patrick. Bière orangée voilée avec une belle mousse. Elle a une belle tenue. Les arômes sont bien agréables aux nez avec des effluves de mangue. Le nez est classique des bières Red Racer on peut lire la signature. Il y a aussi de métal. La bouche est mince, elle manque de corps. Il y a du métal et beaucoup de bulles. Il y trop deffervescence. Encore une fois une bouche qui nest pas à la hauteur du nez.
Pours a terrific amber colour with a frothy white head. Tons of grapefruit in the aroma. Mouthfeel is thick with low carb but itreally works with this flowery bitter flavour. Well done!

355ml can pours a light brown color with a finger of white head which settles to some thin lacing.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts with some grassy and citrusy hops.  Taste is a pleasing hoppy bitterness balanced nicely with some malty sweetness.  Body is light to medium with some pleasing carbonation on the tongue.  This is quite a nice bitter, but I think it is a little overrated on this site.

On cask. Appearance: light brown with a small white head. Aroma: malt, lots of grain, a little hops, some spice and bitterness. Smells great. Flavour: perfume like hops, grains, spice, lots of tea and a bitter finish. Not a bad tipple.
Dark amber brown, rich creamy brown head. Nice toasty malt.Sparkly mouthfeel good balance. Grassy aftertaste. Medium to light body.

355ml can. As soon as I pop the can the grapefruit and orange nose filled my kitchen, before I could even pour. Huge foamy head on the pour, even with the glass tilted like I usually do I had to stop a couple times or it would have overflowed. Colour was a slightly cloudy orange amber. Taste was a good balance between sweet malts, citrus sourness and piney hops. Medium body with lots of carbonation. Overall, a unique ESB, but one worth trying out.

Single can purcahsed from Zyn Liqour in Calgary, AB on 08/14/2011. Colour: A nice light red/brown mix. Big head that quickly faded. Nose: The hops produce HUGE grapefruit!...totally dominates the nose. Twist of caramel. A lemon-lime hint. Crazy... Taste: Medium-light sweet, medium bitter, medium-light sour. Picks up right where the aroma left off - hello grapefruit! A friend joins - orange juice. A nice bitter late kick that is still fruit-dominant. One of the most citrus engulfed brews that has touched my lips...different indeed and not entirely bad!

This was a really nice beer. Would like to have more when my palate isnt so fatigued. Got a bit of bitterness balanced with some nice sweet. I love this style and need to give this beer another chance.

355ml can from tbadiuk. 

Appearance : Clear shiny amber with small white head. Nice colour. Light lacing.

Aroma : Great chewy malts with light fruits and great herbal and earthy hops. Light caramel. Sightly mineral and slightly citrusy. Quite complex and very fresh.

Taste : Earthy and slightly citrusy. Nice malt with light caramel. Finish bitter with earthy and herbal hops. Slightly citrusy. 

Palate : Sharp carbonation but goes down quite well. Quaffable.

Overall : Wow very nice one. Very tasty and complex but really well balanced. Bitterness is rather sharp for the style. Still very drinkable. Nice mix of earthy hops and citrusy notes. Great malt all around (especially on the nose).
33 cl can, Winnipeg, MB, Canada. Medium gold, hop aroma, slightly thick with a syrupy consistency. Nice hoppiness, dry hopped finish.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dune canette de 355 ml, au Mondial de la Bière 2011 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Légère odeur dhoublons et de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est cuivrée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréales et de pamplemousses. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût houblonné. (Rating #3724)

Pours out a solid amber colour that is totally clear. A massive foam up occurred with a bubbly tan look that sticks everywhere. Starts off very fruity hinting at a large hop presence. Apricots and peaches, pungent thickness, caramel, sweet pine. Pretty nice aroma but ESB? Bitter start, apples, apricots, quite tart, orange rind, caramel and sort of bready. Plenty of odd tart pine. Pretty much medium bodied, apricot and bready finish with the notable bitterness. Totally drinkable.

Tasting at the 18th Mondial de la bière, June 10, 2011. Honey copper, thin head. Citrus hop aroma slightly bitter. Slightly citrus hop flavor, not really sweet, good bitterness. Its pretty good, if there is nothing better!

Pours a deep amber, almost brown colour that is quite clear with a big white head. Aroma is slightly malty with a good amount of citrus hops and pine scents. Taste is slightly bitter throughout, not too strong and consistently sweet as well. Medium body, lively carbonation, and a smooth mouth feel. Overall a really good ESB, very enjoyable.

In short: A very nice, moderately hoppy, low-intensity session golden ale
How: Can 355ml.  Consumed fresh about two weeks after purchase.  Can from mcberko, thanks a lot Matt
The look: Clear golden body topped by a persistent small off-white head leaving good lacings on the glass
In long: Nose of leafy hops with oranges notes and light notes of grapefruits.  Taste is just plain light fun.  Crusty bread, leafy hops, woody hops and citrusy hops, a tiny bit resinous, light caramel.  Pleasant somewhat complex hop profile although low on bitterness.  Very mild wooden bitterness.  This is the kind of not-so-tasty session beer that really gets the job done.  I preferred this one over their flagship IPA, I would drink gallons of this fun low-intensity beer.  A very nice Red Racer.  And it is important to note that a person who professionally plays the piano is called a pianist and a person who professional competes in races is called a racer, not a racist.  Although honestly looking at the NASCAR  I think both names apply.

[on tap at Alibi Room, Vancouver]
Creamy aroma with a touch of banana, but plenty of caramel. Notes of fresh fruits, including orange. Clear orange-bronze under a thin, lacy, white cover. Good sweet caramel flavour is balanced by grapefruit peel bitterness. Notes of pine and faint peanuts. Medium body, moderate carbonation, very slight bitter finish that has a touch of sweetness to it.

On tap at Central City Brew Pub. Pours orange/brown. Aroma of English malts and hops - malt more potent, also quite woody. Flavour of perfume, orange peel, with a bitter aftertaste. Much better than any other bitters I have tried!

Very drinkable session ESB. The pour is dark amber with orange highlights. The aroma is mildly malty with a big hoppy note. Grass and light citrus as well. The middle is sweet and malty with toffee and caramel notes. Finish is moderately citrus hopped with a bit of lingering bitterness. A great session ale overall.

Bang on for the style.  This one from Zyn and listed at 5.6% Pours a ridiculous amount of foam and stays like that.  Soft mouthfeel yet the bitterness is right there throughout the pint.  Golden body.  Very drinkable and some hops wafting in the air that invites you in.

Can. Pours out copper color with a nice head, some retention. Aromas of their IPA. Lots of citrus and some gentle grapefruit hops and some malt and a run on sentence.....Taste is more bitter than some IPAs. Mid bodied, mildly carbonated. Lingering bitter aftertaste.Not what I look for in an ESB.

Yet another offering from Red Racer that taste the same as every other beer they make, but at least the beer taste good. This ESB appears to have a clear honey brown body with a tall sticky cap. Aroma is of west coast peach hops and a sweet toffee malt, mild amounts of wet leather. Mmmmmmmm this seems to smell almost identical to their winter ale and pale ale and IPA.mmmmmmmBitter taste thats very west coast. I can kind of taste a true ESB hiding in the flavor but its very shy and doesnt really ever come out. Hints of leather and a watery feel with massive hops is all that this really is. Where is the thick creaminess of the style, where is the bready sweetness?? Whatever they missed the mark for style with their west coast twist but its still an enjoyable beer I would easily drink again.
Red brown with a frothy creamy head, piney hops balanced with a crystal malt sweet aroma, rounded and full with a firm bitter bite... Red Racer continues to impress!

Seems more like a pale than an ESB. Pours a clear amber, thin head. Floral hops in the aroma. Mid range body, doesnt have the grain/bready malt typical of an english esb. Finish is clean floral/citrus hops.

Can, 355 ml, gift from Philippe Boutin (merci!), savoured on February 16 2011; eye: copper with an orangey hue, slightly hazy, minimal effervescence, beige head that turns into a tiny ring, nice lacing; nose: resinous hops, floral hops, light grapefruit, light orange; mouth: resinous hops, grapefruit, slight orange, malt, dry finale in resinous hops with light presence of orange, medium body, good carbonation, rather bitter, nice enjoyable astringency, harsh texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Canette, 355 ml, cadeau de Philippe Boutin (merci!), savourée le 16 février 2011; il : cuivrée avec une teinte orangée, très légèrement voilée, effervescence minime, mousse beige qui se transforme en un petit anneau, bonne dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, houblon floral, léger pamplemousse, léger orange; bouche : houblon résineux, pamplemousse, très léger orange, malt, finale sèche en houblon résineux avec légère présence dorange, corps moyen, bonne carbonatation, plutôt amère, bonne astringence agréable, texture rugueuse en résumé : bien bon

Delicious!  Smells great.  Awesome rich colour.  Poured from can with little head (maybe just my pour).  Tastes great.  Not too bitter, wont scare away a lager-swilling macro kind of guy.  Dry, hoppy finish.  I cant wait to visit the Central City brew pub in surrey!

med amber color. Full bodied. Full malty backbone 
with some earthy notes and wood.  Subtle hops in the finish.  More  like a malty amber than a red ale, but nice simple beer.

355ml can. Orange coloured, clear, a good foamy head. Aroma has
Citrus notes, some orange sweetness. Some crystal malt flavor, hint of nut
And grapefruit flavors. Moderate bitter aftertaste. Medium body and carbonation. Very nice, well rounded esb. Will visit this one again.
Okay clear amber body with modest head on top. Very hoppy aroma but nothing else on the nose. Flavour is all hops with a bitter finish. It does what it says, and it says what it does. And thats it.

Can.  Pours a reddish amber with a thin but lasting white head.  Spicy hopped aroma.  Taste - starts bitter.  Earthy, some citrus/grapefruit in the bitterness.  Moderate malt body, some caramel.  Finishes with an earthy bitterness.  Very good for an ESB, top of the class for sure.  Would like to try this out of a cask!

Amber orange pour, large, dense white head that leaves bubbly lacing.  Floral, citrus, and caramel aroma, lots of hops.  Light caramel malty body, more of those floral hops with citrusy notes.  Drinks much more like a pale ale than an ESB, as it doesnt have much of that bready sweet maltiness I tend to associate with ESBs.  To style or not, this has good hop aromatics.

Very well hopped aroma of Fruit, syrup and butterscotch and pine needles. Great copper colour with a decent frothy white head and lace. Disappointingly thin in texture. Crisp hop flavour with hints of malt.

pours almost auburn and red with good head. The aroma smells super hoppy and pine cone like id mistake this for an IPA if I wasnt reading the label. Palate is again hoppy up front but fisnishes a bit thinner than IPAs. good to great stuff. it screams West Coast, especially given its style.

355ml can. Pours amber/orange with with foamy off-white head. Very spicy, spruce needle hops on the nose with a hint of....nuttiness? Slightly sweet entry with a dominant hop character all the way through a long bitter piney finish. Possibly over-hopped for the style but enjoyable all the same.

Canned sample. Pale amber in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of juicy pink grapefruit, fresh leafy hops, and nutty malts. More grapefruit upfront in the mouth, along with elements of black pepper, and lemon rind, and lightly toasted nuts. Very dry and virtually divoid or caramel flavors. Medium bodied. Clearly not very ESB like with all of the citric hops and fairly clean yeast profile, but very drinkable. I appreciate that its less dank and caramelly than their IPA.
GCBF 2010. Luscious aroma of earthy toffee and ripe papaya. Fruity caramel palate, heaps of ripe tropical fruits. Medium bitterness. A beer I could drink all day.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 12 ounce can sample - pours a deep hued orange with an impressive frothy off white head. Nose-big punch of herbal and citrus hops. Taste- very hoppy, tropical fruits and a sweet caramel and cereal base. Not an ESB in the true sense of the style, but quite tasty anyways, although hops are somewhat out of balance.Drinkability is good as long as you really enjoy your hops. Body fairly light.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 A - Storng citrus....ummmmm
A - Amber with thick long lasting head
T - Dry and sour with a long lasting and strong bitter finish
P - Oily texture with medium carbonation
O - This is one of those breweries that gives people something unique, not just the genaric usual...and I love them for this.

355 mL can.  Translucent amber-brown with a small but sticky white head.  This one has the aroma and some of the malt profile of an ESB, but otherwise seems closer to an Amber.   The malt gives us nuts, caramel, toast, and even a little anise.  The hops are sweet citrus early but become earthy near the end.  Lovely bitterness throughout.  Great beer!

Can [355ml] courtesy of Mirek. Pours a clear amber-copper with a large lasting frothy off-white head. Decent lacing on the glass. Nice aroma of floral hops, citrus, tropical fruit and slightly toasted caramel malt -- hoppier then I expected, in a good way. Flavour follows the aroma with lightly toasted caramel malt, a good amount hops, fruit and a mild but decent bitter finish. Average to medium bodied. Im not sure if its right on style but I dont care, this is a really good beer and one Id be happy to buy regularly were it available here.

355ml can (thanks, Paul!!).  Amber-copper pour, clear, bubbly, with a smallish fizzy white head.  Im sorry, but ESB?  Really?  Smells friggin great, but its all toasty malt, cereal/rye grain and plenty of resin/citrus hops.  The taste is mostly cereal grain and resin bitterness, with noticeable alcohol - take the alcohol and hoppiness down about 60% and you might make me think ESB - but hell, it tastes really, really good, so who cares?  Average body, chewy and lively mouthfeel, nice grainy/bitter finish - liked it!!

Can from Brewery Creek. Pours a coppery red color with a thin white head. The aroma is dominated by fruity hops. Flavor of fruity hops, caramel and malt. The body is light with an oily texture and moderate carbonation. Its atypical for an English style ESB, more of a modest variant of the vastly superior IPA by the same brewer.
on tap @ the Alibi Room, Vancouver. A very good ESB IMO> Solid hop presence in the aroma. Medium caramel color. Well balnced flavor with solid hop presence. Seek out when in BC
On tap at Alibi. Dark amber with a lasting short foam and lacing. Mt and hop aroma similar to APA. Tasty creamy hoppy malty beer. Refreshing, hoppy and filling.

On tap at the Alibi Room - pours a golden/red with a small white head. Aroma and flavour are slightly hoppy and bitter. This is like a way weaker version of the Empire IPA - drinkable and refreshing, but no where near as satisfying as the IPA.

Name: Boomers Red (ESB)
Date: September 06, 2009
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub
Appearance: clear copper, fine off white head, lots of lace
Aroma: sweet caramel aroma, floral and earthy hops
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, caramel and crystal sweetness, touch of breadyness, well balanced earthy and woodsy hops
Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.7/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4

Poured from a Growler. Beautiful red-brown with a small, white head. Aroma of caramel and flowery hops. Balanced flavor of sweet toasted malt and medium hops upfront, light  red and citrus fruits with a bitter-sweet finish. Palate was smooth, resinous and highly drinkable. I will definitely be re-filling my growler with this one, plays well at parties.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 On tap. Pint at Alibi Room. WOW! Big hop taste and medium body. This is also a good looking reddish brown beer. Not much head, though. Strong grapefruit flavour balances the nice hop bitterness. Piney! I will have this one again to be sure. Great effort by Central City!

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear medium orange color. The head was off white and left some lace on the glass. Nice balance of flowery hop and caramel in the nose. Light to medium bodied and delicately sweet up front with mild bitterness at the end. The flavors followed the aromas, but there was also some distinct pine at the end. Good stuff.

On draught at the Central City Brewpub in Surry, BC. Pours a clear copper amber brew with some red highlight in the disk top and a fast dissolving off-white head that leaves behind a thin film and no ring. Aroma of caramel malt, some citrus zest and grassy hops. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of caramel malt, citrus zest and a touch of lemon. Finish is semi-dry with a mild bitterness that slowly disappears. One of Central Citys better beers Ive tried.

Dark amber brown, rich creamy brown head. Nice toasty malt.Sparkly mouthfeel good balance. Grassy aftertaste.
Medium to light body.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2010 2010-03-13, draught at Alibi Room, Vancouver, as Red Racer ESB, 7-4-7-3-14=35Hazy amber color. The aroma, malty, is also quite fruity. Sweetish caramel flavor, correct bitterness. The hop gives a pleasant fruit touch, also citrus fruits, but in the end the bitterness is too aggressive.2008-07-30, draught at The Railway Club, Vancouver, as Big Kettle ESB, 7-5-7-5-15=39Hazy amber color, creamy head. Very nice hoppy aroma, fruity (mango) and very light cheese, a bit yeasty. Good and strong toffee flavor, with a very powerful hopping, resiny and fruity; the yeast touch gives it an English facet (side to side with the Phillips IPA, its sweeter, with more character, more fruity, the hop bitterness is less aggressive). Very long final. Lovely.2008-07-21, draught at the brewpub, 6-4-7-4-13=34Nice amber color. Its the upper step from the Red Racer Pale Ale: more body, more caramel flavor, more hop aroma, more bitter, and the hops show more resins and citrus character. Pleasant.2008-07-17, draught at The Alibi Room, Vancouver, as Baby Boomers ESB, 7-4-8-4-15=38Hazy amber color, creamy head. It has a good balanced flavor, caramel, medium sweet, and American hops, with a citrusy and resiny touch (6 hops here, Im told). Very good.

very light brown with a tinge of red. super clear and decent patchy lasting head. smells of almost crap lager. maybe killians.  i cant see this being at ale. also kinda a cloying artifical pistachio character. tastes like metal like the last beer, but has a more reasonably balanced malt front-end.  man, i cant get over that metal.  the balance is surprisingly decent, which makes this a reasonably ESB, until that godawful metal.  the least metallic of the beers ive had in canada so far.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 Pours a light amber/orange with a thin but lasting head and nice lacing. Aroma is very fresh and hoppy with a light malty sweetness. Tastes fantastic! Good bitter anglo-hopping, cuts right through with a faint lemon-pith finish. Nice and malty but never cloying or sweet, just perfectly balanced. Great carbonation, foam keeps each sip nicely aerated. What a well-balanced perfectly-executed ESB. Big props to Central City - what a winner!

On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ City Brewery:  Chill haze redish brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is citrus hoppy. Flavor starts with a rich burnt caramel followed by grapefruit finishing lightly dry with a grapefruit rind aftertaste. Medium bodied and smooth with lively carbonation.
Pours an iced tea coloured red hue with a thin white head. Nice grapefruit aroma. Fairly hoppy flavour with a nice malt balance. Extremly drinkable. Good session beer.

On tap at Railway Club, Vancouver.  Labelled as Kettle ESB. Amber colour with lasting of white head. Odd beer, some malty berry flavour, some nicely balanced hop.  Nice malt/red fruit aroma.  Some nice spicey hop on finish. Dries the roof of the mouth on finish. Bit of yeast on aroma. Quite full in mouth. Then too strong hop on finish rather throws it out of balance. Drinkable though.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 Growler: Pours a nice copper colour with a good off white head. 
Aroma is medium malt and nice subtle hop, grapefruit.
Flavour is a medium bitter, quite pleasant. 
I hadnt realized that this was a bitter, thought it was just a N.A. Red ale.
Will enjoy the rest of this bottle.
On tap at Central City.  Copper colour with medium body & carbonation . Citrus in the nose,  pleasant bitter finish. Good session beer.  Im drinking lots of these!

(Draught) 6oz sample glass reviewed at the brewery. A great beer! Light-headed, frothy foam atop a mildly carbonated copper body. Nose is very pleasant orange-zest with an oily composition. The tongue lashes with full orange and lemon oil (Pledge?). Lasting bitter finish. Delicious!
Copper coloured with big creamy head and excellent lacing. Not overly hopped but pleasantly bitter and a lot of malt. Very well balanced. Another growler for the road!

Ok, this is my favourite local beer and my favourite style - ESB.  Usually only found at the Central City Brewpub in Surrey, BC, it has also found a home at The Railway Club in downtown Vancouver where it is known as Kettle ESB.  Mahogany with a big head. Big malt Big hops Balanced Delicious!

Draught at The Railway Club, Vancouver.  Clear reddish amber, thick creamy head. Aroma of licorice and roasty malt. Fairly light bodied with clean mouthfeel. The hops adds grapefruit and pleasantly perfumy schampoo as well as good bitterness. The hop character is delicious!

Growler serving: Hazy orange-copper, light sticky white head. A really hoppy ale, piney, foresty, floral, spicy and grassy. Pleasant hop aromatics certainly, though the malt backings stay low profile to say the least, reminiscent of oldish walnuts. Dried leaves and nuts take more room in mouth, while the hop perfume strikes home with a surprisingly innocent bitterness. Quite light bodied unfortunately and not without watery aspects despite the very high carbonation level.

Soapy, floral, lavender hops greet the nose along with a light nutty aroma.  Clear amber body with a low but lasting, fine bubbled head.  Simple, clean, fresh malt flavour with citrus, earthy, floral, lavender, and soapy hops and some tropical fruit esters.  Light medium body with low carbonation.  Growler sampled at Barrys housewarming tasting.  Big thanks to Oakes for dropping this off at my hotel while I was sleeping when I was in Vancouver!

Pours a coppery red color with a thin white head. The aroma is dominated by fruity hops. Flavor of fruity hops, caramel and malt. The body is light with an oily texture and moderate carbonation. Its good but doesnt enflame my imagination, or liver.

The Lure:Citrusy, wooden hops team up with the cranberries to create a distinguished flower breed. Nutritious cereal grounds it all with aplomb, this must be a pleasant pint.

The Festivities:Floral hop flavors follow up into resinous bitterness. Cranberry-like fruitiness lies on adequate crystal malt bread. A quenchable body makes it all go down effortlessly.

Transcendence:Pride in the simple things is as honourable.

64 oz growler shared with  MartinT, tiggmtl, Rastacouere, beerbuzzmontreal and Yowie.  Shy head atop a translucent, almost clear deep red body...flowery, indistinct nose with hints of honey and lightly roasty malt...slight nuttiness in the body, a decent full maltiness, but not terribly exciting...at the end, rather smoky and bitter...reasonably well-made but ultimately dull amber.
dark amber colour with minimal head.  Aroma was malty and slightly earthy with some citrus.  Slightly sweet malty taste, pretty regular.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2005 Dark copper colour.  The aroma has the standard "American amber" mix of earthy crystal malts and floral, slightly citrusy C-hops.  Tastes pretty much like pommelo, eaten fresh in SE Asia.  A little toasty.  Rounded and balanced with a lingering, dry finish.  The most assertive of the Central City beers Ive had to date.
cloudy dark amber colour. small light brown head. malt nose with hops well blended in. bitter grapefruit hop flavour. no lace.
Amber with a touch of red, light fruity hoppy aroma. Wonderful fruity malty complex flavours.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 Hazy deep copper colour, cream off-white head.  Aroma is very leafy/grassy.  Dry-hopped and quite intriguing aroma.  Some sweet toasty malts in back of the dominant hopping.  Flavour is also quite leafy and grassy.  Nice spicy and resiny hop flavour are the first thing you notice.  As the beer warms a bit, the resiny notes fall back bringing out more spicy/woody hop flavour.  Light sweet toffee/bready malts with the faintest touch of cherry esters.  Great balance and highly drinkable.  This beer has really improved since the last time I had it.  I can see this becoming a go-to beer in Vancouver.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Hazy light brown,thin beige head. Good citrus hop nose. Nice grapefruit hop flavor with the amount of balancing malt varying with each batch
